metadata.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kolla Sreerama Murthy

facts.text: Respondent is a dealer in gunny bags manufactured by Chittivalsa and Nellimerla Mills in Visakhapatnam District.
Purchases by respondent from mills on written contract terms: bought-notes via brokers, e.g., Ex. A1 for 30,000 bags from Chittivalsa mills, delivery within 3 months.
Buyer (respondent) required to deposit Rs. 15 per bale within 24 hours, which was fulfilled.
Mills issued delivery orders after deposit; handed to buyer on honoring hundi for value.
Goods answering contract description existed in mills' godown sufficient for delivery at time delivery orders issued.
Respondent endorsed delivery orders instead of taking delivery himself; orders passed through hands; ultimate holder obtained delivery from mills.
At each endorsement, price of bales collected by endorsers, often including profit.
Sales tax assessed on turnover from these transactions for 1947-48 (Rs. 2,941/7/- partly collected) and 1946-47 (Rs. 1,631/12/-).
Respondent filed O.S. No. 268/1951 on July 25, 1951 for 1947-48 and O.S. No. 309/1951 on September 6, 1951 for 1946-47 to set aside assessments and obtain refunds.
District Munsif decreed suits; affirmed by Subordinate Judge on appeal; affirmed by Andhra Pradesh High Court in S.A. Nos. 194 and 195 of 1954 on June 27, 1957.
High Court granted certificates under Art. 133(1)(c) for appeals to Supreme Court.
Common understanding that mills would honour endorsements and deliver to endorsee.
Delivery of goods to ultimate endorsee admitted by all courts.
Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 amended by Madras Act VI of 1951 on May 15, 1951 adding s.18A barring suits to set aside assessments.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transactions involving endorsement of delivery orders by respondent constituted sales of goods within Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 so as to attract tax under s.3 on the turnover.
Whether suits were barred by s.18A inserted by Madras Act VI of 1951.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent is a dealer carrying on business of buying/selling goods; transactions were sales of goods taxable under s.3.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 ss.2(c), 2(h), 3; Bayyana Bhimayya v. Govt. of A.P.

petitioner_arguments.text: Endorsements created separate sales: mill to respondent, respondent to third parties; delivery orders are documents of title under Sale of Goods Act s.24.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bayyana Bhimayya v. Govt. of A.P.; Butterworth v. Kingsway Motors Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suits barred by s.18A as not maintainable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 s.18A (added by Madras Act VI of 1951)

respondent_arguments.text: Transactions were mere endorsements/transfers of delivery orders, not sales of goods; no appropriation of goods to respondent's contract before endorsement; no property passed to respondent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 ss.2(h), 3

respondent_arguments.text: s.18A has no retrospective effect; alternatively unconstitutional under Art.19(1)(f)(g).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Act VI of 1951; Constitution Art.19(1)(f)(g)

respondent_arguments.text: No proof goods delivered to ultimate endorsee.

court_reasoning.text: At contract date, no appropriation, only agreement to sell; on delivery order issue, goods appropriated but respondent endorsed without taking delivery, enabling endorsee to take delivery and property pass to endorsee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Endorsement effects sale by respondent to endorsee; delivery order is document of title.

court_reasoning.text: Two separate sales: mills to respondent (via agent), respondent to third parties; feeds defective title principle as in Butterworth.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Bayyana Bhimayya; distinguishes lower courts' view.

court_reasoning.text: Delivery to endorsee admitted; no basis for respondent's non-delivery claim.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All courts proceeded on delivery fact.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide s.18A point as merits favor appellant.

holdings.text: Transactions by endorsement of delivery orders are sales of goods by respondent taxable under s.3 of Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bayyana Bhimayya v. Government of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Endorsements create separate sales; delivery orders as documents of title; two deliveries occur.
Title acquired by ultimate transferee feeds back to benefit intermediate sellers with defective titles.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 (Mad. IX of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines dealer, goods, sale, charges tax on turnover; s.18A bars suits (point not decided).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; constitutional challenge to s.18A (not decided).

statutes_cited.name: Sale of Goods Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Delivery order as document of title.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; judgments of High Court, Subordinate Judge and District Munsif set aside; assessments valid as transactions were taxable sales.
outcome.relief_granted: None to respondent; tax liability upheld.

key_quotes.text: "In so far as the third parties were concerned they had purchased the goods by payment of an extra price, and the transaction must, in law and in fact, be considered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains separate sales via endorsements from Bayyana Bhimayya.

key_quotes.text: "A delivery order is a document of title to goods vide S. 24 of the Sale of Goods Act and the possessor of such a document has the right not only to receive the goods but also to transfer it to another by endorsement or delivery."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to treating endorsements as sales of goods.

key_quotes.text: "These two deliveries might synchronise in point of time, but were separate in point of fact and in the eye of law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes mill delivery from respondent's sale.
